UK

BBC's Laura Kuenssberg said no real progress has been made at the cabinet meeting and no decision have been made but discussions will continue. European Commission stated 'we are not there yet' on a Brexit deal, there has been no breakthrough. (Newswires)

UK PM May briefed her inner cabinet on Thursday evening that a historic Brexit deal is close. An official close to Brexit talks said that May never brings the cabinet together to tell them what is going on, feels like the deal is practically done. She also said Brexit backstop talks are likely to continue until November. (Newswires)

DUP leader said PM May could not in good conscience recommend a deal which places a trade barrier within the UK. In related news, EU's VP Jobs Commissioner Katainen said the commission’s interest is to convince the Italian government to take responsibility on the budget, and added that it is not too late to show that public finances are on a credible path. Finally, the minutes added that high frequency indicators stabilised, highlights robustness of expansion. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 11th October 2018: Stocks extend rout; Trump renews Fed criticism
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, crude down, dollar down.

* REAR-VIEW: Trump says Fed ‘out of control’, US CPI soft, ECB sources say it won’t come to Italy’s rescue without bailout, Japan monitors market moves, Italian Senate approves budget deficit target, OPEC monthly report production rises whilst demand weakens.

* AHEAD: Germany CPI Final, IEA Monthly Oil Report, US Import/Export Prices, Chinese Trade Balance. Fed's Evans and Bostic to speak, ECB's Lautenschlager and Draghi to speak, US Banks kick off earnings season.

 

* FED/US ECONOMY: US President Trump once again expressed criticism over the Fed, stating the Fed is ‘out of control’ and noting it is far too stringent and making a mistake. He added he is not going to fire Fed Chair Powell, but he is just disappointed. On the economy, he emphasized that having a strong dollar is not good for exports. In previous comments, NEC Director Kudlow stated the Fed is independent, highlighting the President has his own ideas. He interpreted yesterday’s equities sell off move as a market correction, noting that the economy is very strong, but corrections do happen. He went on to explain that strong economic data can feed into strong stock market. Fed's George (hawk, non-voter) says gradual rate hikes needed, pace and extent of hikes are a key part of the FOMC's deliberations; risks to US economy are balanced but inflation could rise over the next couple of years

* TRADE: US President Trump said that his policies have impacted the Chinese economy and he 'has a lot more to do'. NEC Director Kudlow announced that Trump and Xi might meet at the G20 summit. Elsewhere, EU Commissioner Malmstrom said Europe is mulling not negotiating with the US on trade, adding that Trump's strategy is working. She also said EU is open to US talks on all industrial goods and cars. Later comments from the US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, where he said the US is committed to fair trading agreement with China as well as fair and reciprocal trade deals.

* ITALY: Italy's Senate voted to push the balanced budget goal beyond 2021, and approved the budget deficit target. The details of the plan remained in focus today with authorities expressing their views. The Italian Pension Chief said the plan would further increase 2021 pension spending by 1% of GDP whilst lowering the retirement age will cost future generations approximately EUR 100bln. Deputy PM Salvini reiterated he will not take even a cent off of the budget measures. On the EU side, Commissioner Moscovici said he has not rejected the plan yet. ECB sources reported that the central bank will not come to Italy's rescue if government and banks run out of cash unless EU bailout in place, adding that the OMT programme is conditional on bailout program, and that large-scale emergency liquidity assistance may also require ECB approval, and could be conditional on a bailout programme.

* ECB MINUTES: stated the main factors behind the growth slowdown may not be transitory, adding that trade tensions could lead to more general decline in confidence. They noted adverse effect of trade tensions are so far limited, but might still impact the Euro area more significantly over time. They said the domestic economy showing resilience and is mitigating downside risks. They stressed high frequency indicators have stabilised highlighting robustness of expansion. Finally, they highlighted domestic cost pressures are strengthening and broadening.

* BREXIT: The European Commission stated on Thursday 'we are not there yet' on a Brexit deal, stressing there has been no breakthrough in negotiations. Similarly, the Irish Foreign Minister said that there is not an agreement on a way forward on a Brexit deal yet, and it is too soon to claim there is an agreement yet. Elsewhere, DUP lawmaker Sammy Wilson said if PM May breaks promise to the DUP then they will have no choice but to vote against her; he is also hopeful that he will not have to exercise threat to vote against the budget, noting that PM May has shared some details with the DUP which has made them nervous. Later reports in The Telegraph suggested UK PM May is facing a cabinet revolt over her new backstop plan amid concerns that it will keep Britain in a customs union with Brussels indefinitely. A spokeswoman then announced that Britain still intends to set out new proposals on regulatory aspects of Northern Ireland backstop in due course. As a side note, the budget is due to be released on October 29th, in-between the October and November summits. In late trade, the FT reported that UK PM May briefed her inner cabinet on Thursday evening that a historic Brexit deal is close.

* CPI rose 0.1% in September, a touch below the 0.2% consensus, and the headline declined to 2.2% YY, slightly below expectations of 2.3%. Core CPI rose 0.1% m/m and posted at 2.2%, both below consensuses. The Core measures were held down by used car prices which were down 3.0% whilst apparel and healthcare prices rose. Nonetheless, the latest inflation release is unlikely to change the Fed’s interest rates trajectory with money markets currently pricing in ~78% probability of a hike at the December meeting, analysts at Pantheon argued, “the Fed is focused on the very tight and tightening labour market and the threat of much faster wage gains” adding “rates are being raised because of future inflation risk; these numbers don’t change that, and in any event a reversion to the core trend, 0.2%, is a very good bet for October”.

* JAPAN FINANCE MINISTER ASO said he is carefully watching financial markets moves, including FX which shows volatility; he noted that stock markets are falling sharply globally but he sees the global economy on firm note. He believes it is too simplistic to attribute the recent sell off in emerging markets to the Fed raising rates. He urged G20 to be vigilant in increasing capital outflows from EMs and noted some risks to global economy are materialising. He said to have not discuss Forex or Trade in the meeting with Mnuchin. Also, a Senior Japan Finance Ministry official stated it is necessary to consider some kind of response if market moves remain very volatile.

* SPX -2.06% at 2728, NDX -1.14% at 6964, DJI -2.13% at 25053. SECTORS: Energy -3.09%, Materials -1.19%, Industrials -2.27%, Cons Discretionary -1.70%, Cons Staples -2.31%, Healthcare -2.66%, Financials -2.93%, Tech -1.27%, Telecoms -0.84%, Utilities -1.97%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Stock Specifics: L Brands (LB) was a top mover after announcing it was pursuing all alternatives for its La Senza brand. Walgreens (WBA) and Delta Airlines (DAL) rose on the back of beating earnings estimates, Walgreens cited strong profit growth from its acquisition of Rite Aid (RAD) stores. Other gainers included Newmont Mining (NEM) and superconductor co. Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM). Engineering co. Fluor (FLR) was a bottom mover following lower than expected preliminary Q3 revenue. CVS (CVS) dipped lower ahead of its acquisition of Aetna (AET). Dollar Tree (DLTR) moved lower after it announced the upcoming hiring of 25,000 associates. Mylan (MYL) and TransDigm (TDG) were also big losers on the day.

* WTI (X8) SETTLES USD 2.20 LOWER AT USD 70.97/BBL, BRENT (Z8) SETTLES USD 2.83 LOWER AT USD 80.26/BBL. Crude is red again on Thursday, with the same cocktail of factors providing downside catalysts (global risk aversion and equity weakness pressuring crude, talk of sanction waivers for buyers of Iranian crude, as well as the IMF trimming its world growth view this week); additionally, oil platforms in the GoM are coming back as producers allow staff to return as the extreme weather abates. The complex was sliding all day, and the DOE reporting a larger than expecting headline crude stocks build did nothing to help (Crude +5.99mln, Cushing +2.36mln); products were mixed, with distillate stocks drawing by 2.66mln, while gasoline stocks built by 951k; crude production rose 0.9% in the week taking it to 11.2mln BPD. Earlier in the session, the OPEC MOMR saw additional non-OPEC production growth, in line with the EIA's STEO, with a 200k bpd increase from a month ago. Tomorrow, the IEA report will be eyed.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE 20+ TICKS HIGHER AT 118-12+. Treasuries ended Thursday session in positive territory as equities extended their rout and CPI numbers missed expectations. The yield curve bull-flattened with short dated yields lower by c.4bps and long dated yields down by c.9bps at settlement. 2s30 5s30s were narrower by c.3bps.The US Treasury sold USD 15bln of 30-year bonds, stopping through by 0.9bps at a high yield of 3.344%. Demand for the auction was strong as indicated by the bid-to-cover which stood above recent averages. Directs were awarded the biggest share since April, indirects also took the largest portion since January whilst dealers were left with the smallest share since January.   

* USD: The Greenback has dipped again amidst more benign US inflation data and barbs from President Trump against the Fed for tightening the monetary screws too far. However, the index appears to have survived a test of 95.000 and a key Fib level a fraction below the big figure ahead of its 100 DMA (circa 94.980 and 94.850 respectively). 

* NZD, AUD, SEK: The antipodean Dollars have both extended rebounds from new multi-month/year lows vs their US counterpart and back up through round number/psychological levels that have been hampering the Kiwi and Aud, at 0.6500 and 0.7100 respectively. Meanwhile, the Sek continues to test chart resistance vs the Eur in wake of forecast beating Swedish inflation data that fuelled December Riksbank tightening prospects and added tangible macro justification to talk about potentially removing NIRP next year from Skingsley. Note, the cross is back on the 10.4000 handle having declined to within a whisker of the mtd base earlier (10.3750 vs 10.3725).

* EUR: A top performer in G10 behind AUD, almost touching 1.1600 vs the Usd after breaching upside chart levels between 1.1572-94, but not quite reaching big option expiries between the big figure and 1.1620. The single currency has subsequently faded to retest bids/support ahead of 1.1550.

* GBP, CAD, CHF: All firmer vs the Buck, but off best levels as Cable continues to encounter offers around 1.3250 on advances and reports that the UK and EU remain some distance from a Brexit deal given certain big issues yet to be resolved. Meanwhile, the Loonie has eked more gains vs its US rival towards 1.3025, largely shrugging off flat Canadian new house prices vs mostly underwhelming US releases (CPI and initial claims vs firmer real wages), and the Franc is back down near 0.9900 vs not far from 0.9850 at one stage.

* JPY: A net, albeit relatively light loser and underperformer following a gradual loss of momentum when 112.00 vs the Dollar held and then slipping below that level. To recap, from a tech perspective 112.16 is a key Fib that could be pivotal on a closing basis, but Wall Street’s performance after Wednesday’s mauling could overshadow chart dynamics. Elsewhere, the JPY has strengthened by around 3 figures over the last few days, and it has not escaped policymakers’ attention; Finance Minister Aso in US hours said that he is monitoring FX levels.

* EM: Most regional currencies remain on course to rack up decent gains vs the Usd, with the Try, Zar and Brl all deriving independent support from upbeat data, but the Lira conscious about Friday’s Turkish court ruling on the release of US Pastor Brunson and the Real still jittery ahead of the Presidential run-off given probes into 1st round victor Bolsonaro’s economic advisor and favoured choice for the high profile position as Finance Minister.

subject: AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 15bln of 30-year bonds on 11 October 2018 at 1800 BST/ 1300 EST
content:
FED SUPPLY: The US Treasury will auction USD 74bln in 3-year (USD 36bln of new paper, Wednesday), 10-year (USD 23bln reopening, Wednesday) and 30-year (USD 15bln re-opening, Thursday); with approximately USD 24bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, the auctions will raise USD 50bln in new cash. UBS notes that the biggest problem for the bond market to deal with this week is UST supply: "The Fed will issue a total of $230bn of securities this week [including bills]. The timing of the auctions could cause the market some issues at a time when it has been struggling to digest larger auction sizes," UBS fixed income strategists said, "on Wednesday the treasury issues both US 3y and US 10y bonds, but the real test for the market will be Thursday's USD 15bn of US 30-year, especially given the recent steepening of the UST curve."

FED ADD-ONS: There are no Fed holdings maturing at the mid-month settlement, TD Securities notes. The bank also points out that the Fed's balance sheet normalisation plans sees the run-off cap rise to USD 30bln this month.

30-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: Analysts at Societe Generale say the 30-year sector has mixed set-up ahead of Thursday's auction. "The sector is fair on the Treasury spline versus the old 30s, whereas the outright yield is trading above all the auction stops since 2014 and is cheap on the curve since the last auction as 5s30s steepen," SocGen writes. Additionally, it adds that any cover demand from the record short positioning in the sector from the speculators will likely support auction demand. "We are slightly positive on the upcoming bond auction through the upcoming September CPI release before the auction on Thursday, which will likely provide better clarity for the market to setup for the auction."

30-YEAR RECENT AUCTION HISTORY:

  • High-yield: prev. 3.088% vs 6-auction average of 3.068%.
  • Tail: prev. 0.0bps vs 6-auction average of -0.1bps.
  • Bid/cover: prev. 2.34x vs 6-auction average of 2.35x.
  • Dealers: prev. 27.0% vs 6-auction average of 27.6%.
  • Direct: prev. 11.3% vs 6-auction average of 10.5%.
  • Indirect: prev. 61.7% vs 6-auction average of 62.0%.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: DXY down, but not quite out as risk sentiment stabilises
content:
USD

The Greenback has dipped again amidst more benign US inflation data and barbs from President Trump against the Fed for tightening the monetary screws too far. However, the index appears to have survived a test of 95.000 and a key Fib level a fraction below the big figure ahead of its 100 DMA (circa 94.980 and 94.850 respectively).  

NZD/AUD/SEK

The antipodean Dollars have both extended rebounds from new multi-month/year lows vs their US counterpart and back up through round number/psychological levels that have been hampering the Kiwi and Aud, at 0.6500 and 0.7100 respectively. Meanwhile, the Sek continues to test chart resistance vs the Eur in wake of forecast beating Swedish inflation data that fuelled December Riksbank tightening prospects and added tangible macro justification to talk about potentially removing NIRP next year from Skingsley. Note, the cross is back on the 10.4000 handle having declined to within a whisker of the mtd base earlier (10.3750 vs 10.3725).

EUR

Still best of the rest in G10 land and almost touching 1.1600 vs the Usd after breaching upside chart levels between 1.1572-94, but not quite reaching big option expiries between the big figure and 1.1620. The single currency has subsequently faded to retest bids/support ahead of 1.1550.

GBP/CAD/CHF  

All firmer vs the Buck, but off best levels as Cable continues to encounter offers around 1.3250 on advances and reports that the UK and EU remain some distance from a Brexit deal given certain big issues yet to be resolved. Meanwhile, the Loonie has eked more gains vs its US rival towards 1.3025, largely shrugging off flat Canadian new house prices vs mostly underwhelming US releases (CPI and initial claims vs firmer real wages), and the Franc is back down near 0.9900 vs not far from 0.9850 at one stage.

JPY

A net, albeit relatively light loser and underperformer following a gradual loss of momentum when 112.00 vs the Dollar held and now closer to the base of parameters extending to 112.50. To recap, from a tech perspective 112.16 is a key Fib that could be pivotal on a closing basis, but Wall Street’s performance after Wednesday’s mauling could overshadow chart dynamics.

EM

Most regional currencies remain on course to rack up decent gains vs the Usd, with the Try, Zar and Brl all deriving independent support from upbeat data, but the Lira conscious about Friday’s Turkish court ruling on the release of US Pastor Brunson and the Real still jittery ahead of the Presidential run-off given probes into 1st round victor Bolsonaro’s economic advisor and favoured choice for the high profile position as Finance Minister.

subject: DEBT UPDATE: marginal new session lows ahead of US open
content: There may have been some twitchy longs squaring up into the ECB minutes, or tech sellers trying to fill a gap down to 158.12, but Bunds did slip to 158.14 in the run up to 12.30BST before ticking back up again. Note, Gilts followed suit, to 119.81, and US Treasuries retreated further from their best levels, so early US birds may have been selling as well, either taking profit on overnight longs, or simply of the opinion that the safe-haven rally had gone too far and levels look ripe for pre-data plus auction hedging.

subject: OPEC monthly report: OPEC crude production rose 132k bpd in September to average 32.76mln bpd, according to secondary sources
content:
• Crude oil output increased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Libya and Angola, while production declined in Iran, I.R., Venezuela and Algeria.
  • In 2018, oil demand growth is anticipated to increase by 1.54mln bpd, a downward revision of 80k bpd from last month’s projection.
  • For 2019, world oil demand is forecast to grow by 1.36mln bpd, a minor downward adjustment of 50k bpd from the previous month’s assessment
  • Non-OPEC oil supply in 2018 is expected to grow by 2.22mln bpd, an upward revision of 200k bpd
  • Non-OPEC oil supply in 2019 is forecast to grow by 2.12mln bpd, a minor downward revision of 30k bpd
  • OPEC says OECD inventories rose 14.2mln barrels in Aug to 2.841bln barrels, 47mln barrels below the latest 5-year average

subject: PRIMER: ECB September Minutes due to be released Thursday 11th October at 1230BST/0630CDT
content: As was the case with the July meeting, September’s policy announcement delivered little in the way of fireworks with the governing council’s statement broadly unchanged from the prior release. The press conference saw Draghi note that incoming data confirmed the Bank’s previous assessment that growth is broad-based, inflation is rising and the strength of the economy supports confidence. In terms of the latest economic projections 2018 and 2019 growth forecasts were lowered to 2.0% and 1.8% respectively with all other projections maintained. As such, this aspect of the release will likely garner little attention from markets this time around. Instead, markets once again might instead opt to focus on whether there was a more detailed discussion on the Bank’s reinvestment policy; something which Draghi stated was not discussed but will be a topic of discussion at one of the meetings before year-end (note, Draghi’s account of proceedings can differ from the official account). Furthermore, markets are still eager to pin the Bank down on a precise timing for the next rate hike but are likely to be left disappointed by this month’s account. On this matter, ECB’s Knot recently stated that the ECB are comfortable with the wording of forward guidance adding that a hike may come sooner or later than guided. Knot even went on to state that one potential option for the Bank would be publishing how many times they intend to raise rates in a given year. However, such discussions at this stage appear to be more theoretical (possibly confined to the hawks at the ECB) and are unlikely to be detailed in the account of the September meeting; Knot suggested the ECB will begin discussions on the timing of rate lift-off in January. Finally, there might have been some discussion regarding the risks surrounding Italy but such discussions could be considered stale by the market given that the meeting was 4 weeks ago.

European stocks taking the lead from US and Asia with significant losses; Stoxx 600 at lowest in 20 months

Mixed reports on an all-UK agreed backstop, with sources suggesting PM May is to ask her cabinet for approval today

Looking ahead, highlights include, US CPI, US weekly jobs and DoEs

ASIA

Asian stocks drowned in a sea of red following the battered lead from Wall St. amid a sell-off in tech stocks where the sector posted its worst day since 2011. Dow and S&P notched their biggest one-day drop since early February, while Nasdaq fell below its 200 DMA to experience its largest single-day decline since June 2016. There was said to be no one individual catalyst for the sell-off but traders cited concerns over prospective earnings (luxury stocks hit yesterday), ongoing trade concerns, higher yield environment whilst some (including Trump and Mnuchin) suggested a mild correction was overdue. ASX 200 (-2.7%) was dragged lower by the tech sector, closely followed by the energy names, while Nikkei 225 (-3.9%) plumbed the depths amid weakness in mining and energy names alongside currency effects. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-3.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-5.2%) dived deeper into bear-market territory in a continuation of the tech sell-off, with the former hitting lows last seen in February while the latter tumbled to 4-year lows.

EU/UK/US

EU's Moscovici said has not rejected the Italian budget yet. (Newswires)

UK PM May will on Thursday ask her Brexit Cabinet to agree a backstop plan that would keep Britain in a customs union with Brussels until a permanent trade deal can be agreed. Meanwhile, the Sun's political editor tweeted that he was told by a government source that any deal with the EU is "still some way off". (Telegraph/Twitter). Riskbank's Skingsley says bank will likely exit negative interest rate policies in 2019. (Newswires)

US President Trump says he thinks the Federal Reserve has “gone crazy” and reiterated that the Fed is making a mistake and rate hikes are ridiculous. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dovish) said US unemployment rate of 3.7% is "very very low"; he adds that on many the economy is acting as desired and he sees strong US economy for the rest of the year. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) says that despite the surprise on GDP size, the Fed hasn't sped up rate hikes; adding that the Fed has normalized policy quite a bit, and says that we have hit the point where policy rates are at a good position

EQUITIES

Major European indices are all in the red due to the global market turmoil which began on Wednesday in U.S markets (Euro Stoxx 50: -1.3%), the cause has been quoted as a multitude of factors not limited to; US-China trade tensions, the current yield environment, the Italian political situation and suggestions that the markets were overdue a correction. However, it is yet to be seen whether this is part of a broader economic downturn as we enter into U.S earning season with a relatively solid U.S economic backdrop.

All sectors are down with energy firms down by over 2% in fitting with price action in the complex. Healthcare and consumer staples are the best performing sectors as more defensive investments are sought in the risk-off environment, but are both in the red by just under 1%

Dialog Semiconductor is vastly outperforming, up over 23%, following a EUR 600mln deal with Apple, which has led to the company updating their revenue outlook for the next 4 years. Ingenico are also up over 12% after confirmation that Natixis (-4.5%) are in the early stages of take over discussions. Hays Plc are at the bottom of the Stoxx 600, down by 12% after reporting a slower quarterly growth rate.

FX

SEK - Hot on the heels of its Scandi peer, the Sek has seized pole position on the G10 grid and extended gains on the back of relatively hawkish Riksbank rhetoric, as Swedish CPI and CPIF readings also topped market expectations. In response, December rate hike odds have narrowed to better than evens, while Eur/Sek is testing psychological support circa 10.4000 ahead of the nearest downside tech level around 10.3725 (early October low).

NZD/AUD - The next best majors and beneficiaries of the latest Usd downturn (DXY capped below 95.500 within a 95.173-431 range), with the Kiwi extending its recovery from Wednesday’s lows towards 0.6500 and Aud retesting 0.7100. Some additional impetus for the former via less deflationary NZ food prices overnight, while the latter has not really been derailed by RBA’s Lowe advocating higher US interest rates and a stronger Greenback.

EUR - Firmly back above 1.1500 vs the Usd and pivoting 1.1550 within a higher range flanked by hefty option expiry interest (1.8 bn at the 1.1500 strike and 2.3 bn from 1.1600-20), while also facing chart resistance in the 1.1572-91 region that houses a daily top, 55 DMA and Fib. Fundamentally, not much to glean from latest ECB comments, but the minutes may provide something to trade off.

CHF/CAD/GBP/JPY - All moderately firmer vs the Buck, as the Franc cleared resistance at 0.9900, but could not breach 0.9850, and interestingly also retreated from sub-1.1400 levels against the Eur amid suspicions of official intervention. The Loonie is rangebound around 1.3050 ahead of more Canadian housing data, while Cable climbed towards 1.3250 at one stage, but lost momentum and is now back just below 1.3200 where offers have been touted. The Jpy retains an underlying safe-haven bid, but also failed to sustain gains through a big figure, at 112.00, and now eyeing a 50% Fib (112.16) from a tech perspective alongside upcoming US inflation data and related moves in Treasury yields.

EM - The Lira stands out amidst broad rebounds vs the Dollar across the region as Usd/Try crosses the 6.0000 handle to the downside on a combination of more concerted efforts to get runaway Turkish inflation back down towards target and a wider than forecast current account surplus. Elsewhere, the Rand and Real also have data to digest in the form of SA manufacturing production and Brazilian retail sales that might deflect some attention away from domestic politics, for a while at least.

COMMODITIES

Both WTI and Brent are down by 2% at just under USD 72/bbl and USD 82/bbl respectively with prices hampered by the risk-off environment as investors are concerned following global growth uncertainty and ongoing trade disputes. This comes alongside API’s reporting a larger than expected headline build of +9.75mln offering pressure on the fossil fuel. Supply concerns from Hurricane Michael are also easing as oil assets were likely spared significant damage from the storm.

US API weekly Crude Stocks (1 Oct, w/e) +9.75M vs. Exp. +2.62M (Prev. +0.907M)

US API Weekly Gasoline Stocks (28 Sep) +3.4mln (Exp. +1.300mln, Prev. -1.703mln)

US API Weekly Distillate Stocks (28 Sep) -3.5mln (Exp. -1.300mln, Prev. -1.197mln)

US API Cushing Number (28 Sep) +2.3mln (Exp. +1.7mln, Prev. +2.018mln)

Gold is up 0.3% as investors seek safe havens from the current global dip, gold has subsequently breached USD 1200/oz to the upside. Base metals also fell again amidst the broader global risk sentiment with underperformance seen in copper.

FIXED INCOME

Some divergence in core bonds beneath or within the overall asset reallocation from equities bid, as Bunds reversed a little further from early Eurex highs to post a fresh intraday low at 158.26 (+38 ticks) in contrast to Gilts that have ground out a new 120.11 Liffe best (+52 ticks), albeit still lagging somewhat as the core Eurozone debt future rebounds over 158.50 again. Meanwhile, yet more choppy price action in BTPs between 120.48 and 119.44 ahead of Italian supply that was not taken down well, or easily, but appears to have been given the benefit of doubt and enough concession to prevent further fall-out, for now. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are also off overnight safe-haven highs and the curve has unwound a degree of its re-flattening in preparation for long bond issuance that follows CPI and initial claims.

content: Some signs of consolidation and consideration after a frantic scramble off the Eurex open on a mixture of short covering and fresh safe haven buying in anticipation of a sharp drop in EU equities. The positive momentum gathered pace and propelled the 10 year German debt future up to 158.71 (+83 ticks) from an initial 158.33 print and fleeting dip to 158.31, but Bunds have subsequently drifted back down awaiting confirmation and validation before making the next decisive move. Inverse correlations to Italian BTPs are still impacting intermittently, and a decent rebound from 119.50 to 120.44 may also have contributed to the fade in core Eurozone bonds amidst more commentary from Government officials and ahead of hefty supply.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

11th October 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks drowned in a sea of red following the battered lead from Wall St. amid a sell-off in tech stocks where the sector posted its worst day since 2011. Dow and S&P notched their biggest one-day drop since early February, while Nasdaq fell below its 200 DMA to experience its largest single-day decline since June 2016. There was said to be no one individual catalyst for the sell-off but traders cited concerns over prospective earnings (luxury stocks hit yesterday), ongoing trade concerns, higher yield environment whilst some (including Trump and Mnuchin) suggested a mild correction was overdue. ASX 200 (-2.5%) was dragged lower by the tech sector, closely followed by the energy names, while Nikkei 225 (-4.0%) plumbed the depths amid weakness in mining and energy names alongside currency effects. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-3.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-4.3%) dived deeper into bear-market territory in a continuation of the tech sell-off, with the former hitting lows last seen in February while the latter tumbled to 4-year lows.

FTSE

Standard Life Aberdeen (SLA LN) – Co. are reportedly nearing the appointment of Douglas Flint as chairman. (FT)

BT (BT/A LN) – BT shares benefitted from a telecoms rally on Monday, alongside renewed talk of a break-up of the co. This came after investors had been pressuring the new CEO of the co. to consider spinning-off Openreach, a branch of the co. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Bayer’s AG Monsanto unit received a tentative ruling for a new trial regarding the USD 250mln awarded to a groundskeeper who alleged the company’s glyphosate-based weed killers, such as Roundup, caused his cancer. Elsewhere the co. are reportedly considering offloading their animal health unit (no decision has been taken), according to sources. (Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) – BMW said it will take the majority control of its main China joint venture for EUR 3.6bln in the first such move by a global carmaker, amidst Beijing beginning to relax ownership rules over the world’s biggest auto market. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – In a newspaper interview Chief Executive Herbert Diess warned that planned environmental regulations could have dire consequences, including extensive job losses. (Newswires)

Dialog Semiconductor (DLG GY) – Dialog Semiconductor and Apple have entered an agreement, where Apple will pay USD 300mln in cash for transaction as well as prepaying USD 300mln for Dialog products to be delivered over the next 3 years. Elsewhere, The co. have updated their revenue outlook for 2018 to 2022; expects the combined revenue of their advanced mixed signal, connectivity, automotive and industrial business segments are to grow at a CAGR of 10-15% over the period (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

GEA Group (G1A GY) – Co. cuts revenue guidance to show Y/Y growth of +4% vs. Prev. view of +5-6% and sees FY 2018 EBITDA OF around EUR 135mln. (Newswires)

Gerresheimer (GXI GY) – Have increased revenues by 8.8% and successfully integrated Sensile Medical, their Q3 ADJ underlying EBITDA is EUR 79.5mln; revenues at constant exchange rates up 8.8% in Q3 of 2018 to EUR 364.4mln. And their CEO has stepped down. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Ingenico (ING FP) – Natixis (KN FP) is reportedly in the early stages of exploring a takeover of the Co., according to sources. (Newswires)

BNP (BNP FP) – CEO states Co. is on course to hit 2020 targets. (Newswires

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Faurecia (EO FP) – The co. reports Q3 sales at EUR 4.01bln vs. Prev. EUR 3.79bln, and confirmed FY guidance. (Newswires)

Thales (HO FP) / Gemalto (GTO NA) – Gemalto is now expecting to close Thales’ offer for the co. by Q1 2019. 6 of 14 regulatory clearances have been achieved. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Atlantia (ATL IM) – On Wednesday an Italian prosecutor asked a court to sentence Autostrade, per I’Italia CEO Giovanni Castellucci, along with 11 current and former managers at the company to 10 years in jail for alleged multiple manslaughter. (Newswires)

EI Towers (EIT IM) – The takeover bid by 2i Towers won 97.44% of EI Towers capital for an overall value of EUR 1.5bln; the company’s shares are to be delisted on the 19th of October. (Newswires)

Repsol (REP SM) – Q3 production stood at 691k BPD vs. prev. 722k BPD. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

FERRARI (RACE IM) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT JEFFERIES

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – Celltrion’s cancer drug, which is biosimilar to Roche’s blockbuster cancer drug Rituxan, won unanimous backing from an advisory panel to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday. (Newswires)

Flughafen Zuerich (FHZN SW) – Said it handled 2.88mln passengers in September, which is an increase of 4.9% compared to last year. (Newswires)

Novartis (NOVN SW) – Announced new data from the first direct head-to-head trial to demonstrate the greater efficacy of Gilenya over Copaxone in patients which have relapsing remitted multiple sclerosis. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Ceva Logistics (CEVA SW) – The co. said it has rejected an unsolicited non-binding proposal to buy the co. at CHF 27.75/share. (Newswires)

SCANDINAVIA

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 11th October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks drowned in a sea of red following the battered lead from Wall St. after the Dow and S&P notched their biggest one-day drop since early February
  • Traders cited concerns over prospective earnings (luxury stocks hit yesterday), ongoing trade worries, higher yield environment, whilst some (including Trump and Mnuchin) suggested a mild correction was overdue
  • UK and EU have reportedly reached an agreement in principle on an all-UK backstop plan, according to sources
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Swedish and US CPI, US weekly jobs, DoEs and BoE’s Vlieghe

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks drowned in a sea of red following the battered lead from Wall St. amid a sell-off in tech stocks where the sector posted its worst day since 2011. Dow and S&P notched their biggest one-day drop since early February, while Nasdaq fell below its 200 DMA to experience its largest single-day decline since June 2016. There was said to be no one individual catalyst for the sell-off but traders cited concerns over prospective earnings (luxury stocks hit yesterday), ongoing trade concerns, higher yield environment whilst some (including Trump and Mnuchin) suggested a mild correction was overdue. ASX 200 (-2.5%) was dragged lower by the tech sector, closely followed by the energy names, while Nikkei 225 (-4.0%) plumbed the depths amid weakness in mining and energy names alongside currency effects. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-3.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-4.3%) dived deeper into bear-market territory in a continuation of the tech sell-off, with the former hitting lows last seen in February while the latter tumbled to 4-year lows.

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.9098 (Prev. 6.9072) (Newswires)
PBoC skips open market operations for a net neutral daily position

US President Trump does not think Dow declined due to US-China trade war, the market sell-off is correction they have been waiting for, for a long time. Trump said there are more tariffs he can impose on China, but he wants to get a deal. (Fox)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US is concerned with yuan depreciation; while he added nothing "specifically happened today" for markets to react. He also met with PBoC Governor Yi Gang to discuss important economic issues. (Newswires)

IMF Chief Lagarde says the global economy is probably not strong enough; she supported China's move towards currency flexibility

US Trade Representative Lighthizer said to be preparing to negotiate four possible free trade agreements, (Newswires)

UK

UK and EU are said to have agreed in principle on an all-UK backstop plan. UK PM May will on Thursday ask her Brexit Cabinet to agree a backstop plan that would keep Britain in a customs union with Brussels until a permanent trade deal can be agreed. Meanwhile, the Sun's political editor tweeted that he was told by a government source that any deal with the EU is "still some way off". (Telegraph/Twitter)

Germany's Chancellor Merkel said Brexit negotiations in decisive stage and reiterated the desire for a close relationship with the UK, while Netherlands' PM Rutte hopes for a Brexit deal by the EU summit next week. (Newswires)


EU

Italy's PM Conte said that state-controlled companies are ready to invest EUR 15bln additionally in the next five year if the government reforms are implemented. (Newswires)

FX

In FX Markets, the greenback traded on the backfoot following the retreat to sub-95.50 levels to print fresh intra-day lows just under 95.20. Subsequently, EUR/USD found a firmer footing above 1.1550, while GBP/USD reclaimed the 1.3200 handle and approached 1.3250. Elsewhere, USD/JPY tested 112.00 to the downside amid safe haven flows. In terms of antipodeans, NZD outperforms the AUD with the help of an improvement in the Food Price Index, while the AUD/NZD cross fell below 1.0950.

New Zealand Food Price Index Sep -0.1% (Prev. -0.5%) (Newswires)

Brazil election poll: Bolsorano with 58% and Haddad with 42%; first poll looking at run-off ballot. (Datafolha)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the release of Pastor Brunson at the next court hearing on October 12th would be an important step, while Turkish President Erdogan said he has to abide by the court decision on the Pastor. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dovish) said US unemployment rate of 3.7% is "very very low"; he adds that on many the economy is acting as desired and he sees strong US economy for the rest of the year. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (Non-voter, Dovish) said Fed could raise rates until they are lightly restrictive and then pause, the support for further hikes are dependent on economic growth and inflation. He also said it's unusual for the president to comment on monetary policy but asking why rates need to rise is a fair question, while adding the economy is doing quite well on employment and inflation. (Newswires)

RBA's Assistant Governor Ellis said policy needs to be expansionary and monetary policy cannot increase economy's speed limit and productivity. (Newswires)

BoJ's MPC member Sakurai reiterated the central bank needs to continue with easing persistently for the time being, while he reiterates that it is important to continuously check for side effects and added continuing easing under sound macroeconomic environment could cause imbalances to pile up. He also noted the impact from trade protectionism could become larger on a global trade and supply chains. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent continued to sell off with the former losing the USD 72.00/bbl handle while the latter tested USD 81.50/bbl to the downside. The US weekly APIs printed a larger-than-expected build in crude stocks, although, the initial reaction was muted. NHC reported that Hurricane Michael has weakened to a tropical storm over South-Central Georgia, storm flooding gradually decreasing along the Gulf Coast. Some traders cite the decline in oil to the EIA stating that US production is to grow faster than expected, while others simply note a correction. Nonetheless, the risk-off tone of the market is also weighing on prices. Elsewhere, metals are on the backfoot, with the exception of gold as the yellow metal mirrored USD movement, while copper underperformed amid the risk-averse mood.

US estimated Gulf of Mexico producers cut roughly 42% of oil output due to Hurricane Michael, according to BSEE. (Newswires)

EIA cut forecasts for 2018 world demand growth by 60k BPD and sees 1.52mln BPD and raised forecasts for 2019 oil demand growth by 20k BPD sees 1.49mln BPD. (Newswires)

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (1 Oct) +9.75M vs. Exp. +2.62M (Prev. +0.907M) (Newswires)

US

US Treasuries ended Wednesday session undecided as, despite the general risk-off tone, the heavy supply this week may have limited upside action. Most of the selling action was seen at the long-end of the curve were yields were higher by c.2bps whilst buying action was in the short end sending yields lower by c.2bps. There was little if any movement after PPI data. The complex was taking its cue from the wider risk environment (risk-off) as stocks sold-off, VIX rose, and oil ran into sellers. The US Treasury sold USD 36bln of 3-year notes tailing by 0.2bps at a high yield of 2.989, the highest since May 2007. Demand was weak as indicated by the bid-to-cover which was the lowest since July. Directs took the smallest share since July whilst indirects the biggest portion since June leaving dealers with a share well within recent averages. The US Treasury also sold  USD 23bln 10-year bonds, tailing by 0.3bps; demand was scarce and cover was below the 6-week average. Indirects were awarded the biggest portion since July, directs took the smallest share since February and dealers took the largest share since April. * US T-note futures (Z8) settle 2 ticks lower at 117-24.

US President Trump says he thinks the Federal Reserve has “gone crazy” and reiterated that the Fed is making a mistake and rate hikes are ridiculous. (Newswires)
